title: Qualifications for Elders
shortSummary: Titus Chapter 1 introduces Paul's apostolic authority and his instructions to Titus regarding church leadership in Crete. It emphasizes the importance of sound doctrine, godly character in elders, and the need to confront false teachers for the health and purity of the church.
timeline: c. AD 63-65 - Paul's pastoral instructions to Titus during the early church period

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle who authored the letter, instructing Titus on church leadership and sound doctrine.

keyCharacters.name: Titus
keyCharacters.description: Paul’s trusted companion and spiritual son, tasked with organizing the church in Crete and appointing elders.

keyCharacters.name: False Teachers
keyCharacters.description: Unruly and vain talkers causing division and promoting false doctrines, especially those insisting on circumcision.

keyCharacters.name: Cretans
keyCharacters.description: The people of Crete, described as liars and evil beasts, who require firm correction and sound teaching.

definitions.definition: A church overseer or elder responsible for spiritual leadership and maintaining sound doctrine.
Above reproach in character and conduct, exhibiting integrity and moral excellence.
Dishonest gain or money obtained through corrupt or greedy means.
Those who oppose or contradict sound teaching, often spreading falsehoods.
Myths or traditions not grounded in Scripture that distract from the gospel truth.

outline.heading: Paul’s Introduction and Greeting
outline.description: Paul establishes his authority as an apostle and expresses his relationship with Titus, emphasizing the faith and hope in eternal life promised by God.

outline.heading: Instructions for Appointing Elders
outline.description: Paul commands Titus to appoint elders in Crete, detailing the moral and spiritual qualifications necessary for church leadership.

outline.heading: Warning Against False Teachers
outline.description: Paul warns about deceitful teachers who cause division and promote false doctrines, urging Titus to rebuke them sharply to preserve sound faith.

application: Evaluate and uphold godly character in church leaders to ensure faithful stewardship of the gospel.
Be vigilant against false teachings by grounding yourself in sound doctrine and Scripture.
Practice discernment in rejecting traditions or teachings that contradict biblical truth.
Exercise boldness in correcting error within the church to protect the purity of the faith.

keyVerses.text: For this cause left I thee in Crete, that thou shouldest set in order the things that are wanting, and ordain elders in every city, as I had appointed thee:
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the apostolic mandate to establish church order and appoint qualified leaders.

keyVerses.text: For a bishop must be blameless, as the steward of God; not selfwilled, not soon angry, not given to wine, no striker, not given to filthy lucre;
keyVerses.significance: It sets the high moral and spiritual standards required for church overseers.

keyVerses.text: This witness is true. Wherefore rebuke them sharply, that they may be sound in the faith;
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the necessity of firm correction to maintain doctrinal purity.

keyVerses.text: They profess that they know God; but in works they deny him, being abominable, and disobedient, and unto every good work reprobate.
keyVerses.significance: It warns against hypocrisy and the disconnect between profession and practice.
